questions.prompt: A British organization for members of this field publishes a journal called Ibis ["EYE"-biss].  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this branch of zoology that studies birds.

B.question: Before 2021 a journal now called Ornithology was named after this flightless bird that went extinct in the 19th century.  It lived in coastal areas of the North Atlantic, including Canada and Iceland.
B.answer: great auk [awk] (or Pinguinus impennis; accept The Auk(: Ornithological Advances))

C.question: A sister journal, also renamed Ornithological [OR-nih-thuh-"logical"] Applications in 2021, was previously named for this type of vulture.  This bird's "California" species has the largest wingspan of any bird in North Amer ica.
C.answer: condor (accept California condor; accept The Condor(: Ornithological Applications))

questions.prompt: Many authors have voiced a debt of gratitude to Edgar Allan Poe.  For 10 points each -

A.question: This creator of Sherlock Holmes said that Poe's character C. Auguste Dupin ["C" oh-GOOST doo-pan] "breathed life" into detective fiction.

B.question: An acrostic [uh-"CROSS"-tik] poem dedicated to Poe is among the rare poems by this horror author, who is better known for creating the evil deity Cthulhu [kuh-THOO-loo].
B.answer: H. P. Lovecraft (or Howard Phillips Lovecraft)

C.question: This author of the novel It claims that Poe "wasn't just a mystery-suspense writer.  He was the first."

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about the delta of the Danube River:

A.question: Most of the Danube delta lies in this Eastern European country, which contains the historical regions of Moldavia [mohl-DAY-vee-uh] and Wallachia [wah-LAY-kee-uh].

B.question: The Danube River empties into this sea north of Turkey.
B.answer: Black Sea

C.question: The Danube's delta is the second-largest in Europe; the largest river delta is that of this river, the longest in Europe, which empties into the Caspian Sea.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about the various ways in which french fries are prepared:

A.question: Gravy and cheese curds are poured over french fries in this dish, which is especially popular in Canada.

B.question: In the Netherlands, fries are most commonly dipped in this condiment made from oil and egg yolks.
B.answer: mayonnaise

C.question: In 2016 McDonald's restaurants in Japan began selling fries coated with this ingredient, which forms the outer layer of Pocky.

questions.prompt: This person was known as the "Maid of Orléans" [orr-lee-OWN].  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this person canonized in 1920, centuries after being burned at the stake by a pro -English bishop in 1431.
A.answer: (Saint) Joan of Arc (or Jeanne d'Arc; prompt on "Joan" or "Jeanne")

B.question: Joan of Arc's birthplace at Domrémy [dohm-ray-MEE] is now located in this European country.
B.answer: France (or French Republic or République française)

C.question: Joan assisted a French king with this name in reaching his coronation ceremony.  The tenth French king with this name was overthrown in the July Revolution.
C.answer: Charles (accept Charles VII ["the seventh"] or Charles X ["the tenth"] or Charles-Philippe)

questions.prompt: In the Gospel of John, this figure says "unless you see signs and wonders, you will not believe."  For 10 points each-

A.question: What subject of the Gospels performs miracles including exorcisms, feeding a multitude, and walking on water?
A.answer: Jesus (the) Christ (or Jesus of Nazareth or Yesua or Yeshua or Iesous; accept any underlined portion)

B.question: Jesus miraculously turns water into wine while visiting this kind of celebration at Cana [KAY-nuh].
B.answer: wedding (accept marriage ceremony; accept wedding feast or marriage feast; prompt on "feast")

C.question: Jesus tells Peter that he will find a coin for paying the tax of the temple at Capernaum [kuh-PUR-nay-um] in the mouth of one of these animals.  Peter's previous profession involved capturing these animals.

questions.prompt: The name of these features comes from a Norse word for "to gush."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name these geologic features that intermittently erupt superheated wate r and steam.

B.question: A geyser is a dramatic example of this geologic feature, which is a point where groundwater from an aquifer flows directly out on the surface.
B.answer: spring(s) (accept hot springs)

C.question: Geyserite ["geyser"-ite], which forms in the pipes of geysers, is mostly made up of this mineral.  This material common in sand is often made into moisture-reducing, gel-like beads.
C.answer: silica (accept silicon dioxide; prompt on "quartz" or "SiO2"; do not accept or prompt on "silicate(s)")

questions.prompt: As of April 2022, there are less than 40 inmates at this location.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this detention camp created in 2002 during the "War on Terror."  Located in the Caribbean, this place remains open despite calls for the president to shut it down.
A.answer: Guantánamo [gwahn-TAH-nah-moh] Bay detention camp (accept Gitmo; accept Camp Delta)

B.question: The Guantánamo Bay camp is on this island, which an American-backed force attacked in the Bay of Pigs invasion.
B.answer: Cuba (or Republic of Cuba or República de Cuba)

C.question: This other prison was central to an Iraq War scandal in which U.S. soldiers were photographed mocking and torturing naked prisoners.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-name these countries with unusual flags:

A.question: Mount Everest is on the border of China and this country, which features the world 's only non-quadrilateral [kwahd-ruh-LAT-uh-rul] flag.
A.answer: Nepal (or Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal or Sanghiya Loktantrik Ganatantra Nepal)

B.question: An AK-47 is featured on the flag of this country, which shares its name with the channel separating Madagascar from mainland Africa.
B.answer: Mozambique [moh-zam-BEEK] (or Republic of Mozambique or República de Moçambique; accept Mozambique Channel)

C.question: In 2009 this country adopted a dual flag called the Wiphala [wih-PUH-luh] to represent its indigenous people.  The colonial Spanish silver mines at Potosí [poh-toh-"SEE"] were in what is now this country.
C.answer: Bolivia (or Plurinational State of Bolivia or Estado Plurinacional de Bolivia)

questions.prompt: In 2019 a brick thrown by protestors killed janitor Luo Changqing [loo-OH chang-CHING] in this city.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this "special administrative region" that is currently led by Carrie Lam, who in April 2022 announced she would not seek another term.
A.answer: Hong Kong (or Hong Kong Special Administrative Region or Xianggang Tebie Xingzhengqu)

B.question: The protests were sparked by a bill that would have added China to the list of countries with which Hong Kong could engage in this legal process.
B.answer: extradition (accept extradite or extraditing; do not accept or prompt on "deportation")

C.question: Despite the protests, this president of China ensured the passage of the Hong Kong National Security Law in June 2020.
C.answer: Xi Jinping [shee jin-peeng] (or Xí Jìnpíng; do not accept or prompt on "Jinping")

questions.prompt: This illness is sometimes colloquially called "hydrophobia."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this disease transmitted by the bite of an infected mammal.

B.question: In the 1800s this French scientist developed the first effective human vaccine for rabies with Émile Roux [ay-meel ROO].  He also advanced the germ theory of disease.
B.answer: Louis Pasteur [LOO-ee pass-TUR]

C.question: Pasteur and Roux also developed the first vaccine for this bacterial infection, whose name refers to the coal -black lesions it forms on the skin.  Sheep are particularly susceptible to this disease.

questions.prompt: In 2021 a book named for this street was withdrawn from publication by the author's estate, due to "hurtful"  imagery.  For 10 points each -

A.question: In a 1937 children's book, Marco imagines an increasingly fantastical procession along what title street?
A.answer: Mulberry Street (accept And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street)

B.question: And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street was the first children's book by this writer and illustrator, who later wrote The Cat in the Hat.
B.answer: Dr. Seuss [sooss or soyss] (or Theodor Seuss Geisel)

C.question: The second children's book by Dr. Seuss was named for this boy, whose "500 Hats" incur the wrath of King Derwin.
C.answer: Bartholomew Cubbins (accept either underlined portion; accept The 500 Hats of Bartholomew Cubbins)

questions.prompt: This religious movement began in the early 1900s with the Azusa [ah-ZOO-suh] Street Revival.  For 10 points each -

A.question: The fastest-growing religious movement in the world is what evangelical Protestant movement whose practices include speaking in tongues?

B.question: The Azusa Street Revival took place in this most populous city in Southern Cali fornia.
B.answer: Los Angeles, California (or L.)

C.question: Pentecostalism arose from the teachings of this man and his brother Charles, who were the British co -founders of the Methodist church.

questions.prompt: The wheel on the center of the Indian flag symbolizes this concept.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this Hindu concept which refers to living in proper accord with the cosmic order.

B.question: Dharma is also one of the Three Jewels of this Indian religion founded by Siddhartha Gautama.
B.answer: Buddhism (accept Buddhist religion; accept branches such as Mahayana or Theravada Buddhism)

C.question: One of the earliest references to dharma occurs in this oldest of the Vedas [vay-duz], which begins with the Gayatri ["GUY-uh-tree"] mantra.

questions.prompt: This epoch's name comes from Greek words meaning "whole" and "new."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this geological epoch that followed the Pleistocene ["PLY"-stuh-"seen"] and which most scientists reckon we are still currently in.

B.question: "Holocene" is a song by this indie folk band whose debut album is called  For Emma, Forever Ago.  This band fronted by Justin Vernon is featured on Taylor Swift's song "Exile."
B.answer: Bon Iver [bohn ee-VAIR]

C.question: The later part of the Holocene is sometimes called the Anthropocene [ANN-thruh-puh-SEEN] due to the impact of this species on the world's ecosystems.

questions.prompt: This composer's dissatisfaction with the helicon [HEL-ih-"con"] led to the creation of his namesake variant of the tuba.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this composer of works named after The Washington Post and the Marine Corps motto "Semper Fidelis" [SEM-pur fih-DEH-liss].
A.answer: John Philip Sousa (prompt on "sousaphone" by asking "Who's the composer?")

B.question: Sousa was dubbed the "king" of this genre often performed by military bands.
B.answer: march(es) (accept March King)

C.question: This Sousa march, originally intended for his operetta [ahp-uh-RET-uh] The Devil's Deputy, was renamed after a U.S. landmark.  It was later used as the theme tune for Monty Python's Flying Circus.

questions.prompt: The gamma function shifts and extends this function to complex numbers.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this function that, for a positive integer n, is defined as "n, times n minus 1, times n minus 2, and so on down to 1."

B.question: The factorial function is denoted by this punctuation mark.
B.answer: exclamation point or exclamation mark (accept bang)

C.question: This is the only value that is the result of the factorial function for two different numbers.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about the Battle of Actium [AK-tee-um]:

A.question: This future Roman emperor's fleet won the battle.
A.answer: Augustus Caesar (or Caesar Augustus or Octavian or Gaius Octavius or Gaius Julius Caesar Octavianus; do not accept or prompt on "(Julius) Caesar")

B.question: At Actium, Augustus's forces defeated his former ally Mark Antony, who was supported by this Egyptian queen.
B.answer: Cleopatra (VII Philopator)

C.question: While Octavian and Mark Antony were allies, they joined with Lepidus [LEP-ih-duss] to form this group of rulers.

questions.prompt: This writer criticized "meaningless words" in his essay Politics and the English Language.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this author who invented the word "doubleplusgood" ["double-plus-good"] for a novel set in the totalitarian [toh-tal-ih-TAIR-ee-un] state of Oceania [oh-shee-AY-nee-uh].

B.question: Oceania is the setting of this Orwell novel, which also introduced the words "doublethink" ["double-think"] and "unperson" ["un-person"].  This novel is named for a year.
B.answer: Nineteen Eighty-Four (or 1984)

C.question: In Nineteen Eighty-Four, "doubleplusgood" is an example of this restricted form of English, which the government imposes so dissent will become "literally unthinkable."

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about H II ["H two"] regions:

A.question: They are examples of the "emission" type of these large clouds of gas found in galaxies.  Their name comes from the Latin for cloud.
A.answer: nebulas or nebulae (accept emission nebulas or nebulae)

B.question: The phrase "H II" indicates that H II regions contain hydrogen in this state.  It typically requires 13.6 eV ["E-V"] of energy to shift an atom of hydrogen to this state.
B.answer: ionized (accept answers indicating that the hydrogen is ionized or has lost an electron; accept H+; prompt on answers indicating "(the hydrogen is electrically) charge(d)"; do not accept or prompt on "excited")

C.question: H II regions are often found where these objects have recently formed.  They include red dwarfs and blue supergiants.

questions.prompt: In 1982 chemist Leo Paquette synthesized a compound with formula C20H20 ["C twenty H twenty"] whose carbon atoms form the vertices of one of these solids.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this Platonic solid that has twelve faces.

B.question: A large dodecahedron appears in Reptiles, a lithograph depicting tessellation [teh-suh-LAY-shun] by this Dutch artist.  His print Relativity depicts unusually arranged doors and staircases.
B.answer: M.

C.question: Escher [EH-shur] (or Maurits Cornelis Escher)   A character named the Dodecahedron leads the protagonists to the court of the Mathemagician in Digitopolis in this 1961 novel.

questions.prompt: This man was known as the "Hero of the Two Worlds" for his roles in both the French Revolution and t he American Revolution.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this French marquis [mar-KEE], who received a serious leg wound at the Battle of Brandywine.
A.answer: Marquis de Lafayette [lah-"fie"-ET] (or Marie-Joseph Paul Yves Roch Gilbert du Motier)

B.question: Lafayette and George Washington forced the surrender of Charles Cornwallis at this final major engagement of the American Revolutionary War.
B.answer: Battle of Yorktown (or Siege of Yorktown)

C.question: The first joint operation between American and French forces was an indecisive siege of Newport, an important port in this New England state.
C.answer: Rhode Island (accept RI ["R-I"]; accept Battle of Rhode Island)

questions.prompt: Pencil and paper ready.  For 10 points each -answer these questions about an urn holding 7 purple marbles, [pause] 8 blue marbles, [pause] and 1 white marble:

A.question: If a single marble is randomly drawn, what is the probability that it is blue?
A.answer: 1/2 or 50% or 0.50 or 1 in 2 [There are 7 + 8 + 1 = 16 total marbles, of which 8 are blue; 8/16 = 1/2.]

B.question: How many white marbles need to be added to raise the probability of drawing a white marble to one-fourth, or 25 percent?  You have 10 seconds.
B.answer: 4 white marbles [There is currently 1 white marble out of 16.  If w is the number of white marbles added, (1 + w)/(16 + w) = 1/4, so 4 + 4w = 16 + w, so 3w = 12, and w = 4.]

C.question: What minimum number of purple marbles must be added to raise the probability of drawing a purple marble to a value strictly greater than the probability of drawing a blue marble?
C.answer: 2 purple marbles [This requires having more purple marbles than blue marbles; adding 1 purple would make their count equal (8 each), but adding 2 would yield a greater number of purple marbles (9 versus 8).]
